abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Petroleum Exploration
            Promotion Project for Nepal was successful. The project
            achieved its main objectives, institutional capacity was
            strengthened, sustainability is likely with adequate
            funding, and both the Bank and Borrower acted
            satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the need for indigenous hydrocarbons in
            Nepal is great and efforts should continue to be made to
            attract IOCs (International Oil Companies). The terms of
            PSAs (Production Sharing Agreements) offered to oil
            companies should be made as attractive as possible. Second,
            it would be helpful if the regulations requiring a limited
            period during which bids can be accepted is removed. Third,
            the DMG (Department of Mines and Geology) should continue to
            play a central role in coordinating donor financed efforts
            and in finding means of continuing the promotion effort.
            There are sufficient technical personnel in DMG to carry out
            the routine work and their role in assembling and
            reinterpreting data as it is acquired is critical. Lastly,
            funding for technical assistance would be beneficial to
            continue the supervision of ongoing exploration and efforts
            to strengthen the DMG.

docna.cdata!:
Nepal - Petroleum Exploration Promotion
            Project : Credit 1260 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Petroleum Exploration
            Promotion Project : Credit 1260 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The project aims at fostering interest
            amongst foreign oil companies to explore for petroleum in
            Nepal. There has been virtually no exploration for petroleum
            in Nepal except for limited surface geology surveys
            undertaken during the 1960's. An IDA-financed
            aeromagnetic survey in 1980 demonstrated the existence of
            thick sedimentary zones and basement anomalies in the Terai
            Basin which could be indicative of geologic strutures
            capable of trapping hydrocarbons. However, while these
            indications are encouraging, they are as yet too preliminary
            to attract foreign oil companies to undertake exploration
            work without the acquisition of substantial additional
            geological and geophysical data. The project would consist
            of: (i) a seismic survey of about 800 line-km in the Terai
            Basin; (ii) preparation of draft petroleum legislation;
            (iii) geochemical analysis and other studies; (iv)
            exploration promotion; and (v) training of staff in geology,
            geophysics and legal aspects of the petroleum industry. The
            major benefit of the project would be to enhance the
            attractiveness of Nepal as a petroleum prospect, thereby
            encouraging foreign oil companies to undertake the most
            costly phases of exploration. The project would also provide
            temporary employment for some 400-500 laborers.
